title: Is the liars paradox a proof for the undecidability of the halting problem? - Quora

response.answer_text: No - it’s not proof of the halting problem - but the standard proof of the halting problem does rely on a similar paradox. The halting problem proof works like this: Suppose we can write a computer program that can “solve the halting problem” by examining some other computer program and figuring out whether it will halt or run forever.We can modify that program to say: “If the program I’m presented with will halt for some given input - then I will loop forever - but if I find that the program will loop forever, then I’ll halt.”Then you feed the program to itself.If it loops, it must halt but if it halts, it must loop.This is a paradox - ergo, it is not possible to write a program that solves the halting problem.That’s a lot like the liar paradox…but it’s not proven by the liar paradox.
